responses: Hello! How can I help you start your open source journey today?
Hi there! Welcome to OpenSource Compass. Ready to contribute?
Hey! I'm here to guide you through the world of open source. What's on your mind?
I am the OpenSource Compass chatbot. I'm here to demystify open source and help you find your path to contributing.
OpenSource Compass is your guide to the open source world. We provide resources, tutorials, and project directories.
Open source software is code that is publicly accessible for anyone to view, modify, and distribute. It fosters collaboration.
In open source, the source code is made available for anyone to study, change, and improve. It's built by communities.
Start by finding a project you use or like. Look for 'good first issue' labels, fork the repository, and try to fix a small bug.
The best way to start is to read our 'Guides' section. It spans everything from picking a project to submitting your first PR.
Git is a distributed version control system. Essential commands: git init, add, commit, push, pull.
Git lets you manage code versions. Don't worry if it's confusing at first; everyone Googles git commands!
Run 'git init' to create a new Git repository in your current directory.
This command creates a hidden .git folder where Git stores all its tracking data.
Use 'git clone <url>' to download a repository to your local machine.
Cloning creates a local copy of the code so you can work on it.
'git status' shows you which files are staged, modified, or untracked. Run it often!
It's your best friend. It tells you exactly what state your working directory is in.
Use 'git add <filename>' to stage specific files, or 'git add .' to stage everything.
Staging prepares your changes to be committed. It's like putting a letter in an envelope before sealing it.
Stage your files first, then run 'git commit -m "Your message"'.
A commit is a snapshot of your code. Make your messages descriptive and imperative (e.g., 'Fix login bug').
Use 'git push origin <branch-name>' to upload your commits to the remote repository.
This updates the remote branch with your local commits. You might need to authenticate first.
'git pull' fetches changes from the remote and merges them into your current branch.
It's essentially 'git fetch' followed by 'git merge'. Run this before starting work to stay updated.
Use 'git branch <name>' to create one. Use 'git branch' to list them all.
Branches allow you to work on features in isolation. Always use a new branch for a feature or fix.
Use 'git checkout <branch-name>' to switch branches. Use 'git checkout -b <name>' to create and switch.
Note: Newer Git versions allow 'git switch <branch-name>' which is more intuitive.
Switch to the target branch (usually main) and run 'git merge <feature-branch>'.
This combines the history of the feature branch into the current branch.
'git stash' temporarily shelves your changes so you can switch branches without committing.
Use 'git stash pop' to bring those changes back later. Great for quick context switching.
'git cherry-pick <commit-hash>' applies the changes from a specific commit to your current branch.
Useful if you fixed a bug on the wrong branch and want to move just that fix.
Rebasing moves your branch to start from the latest commit of another branch. Keeps history linear.
Use 'git rebase main' on your feature branch to update it. careful: Don't rebase public branches!
'git reset --soft HEAD~1' undoes the commit but keeps changes staged. '--hard' deletes changes entirely (be careful!).
Useful for fixing the last commit or clearing your working directory.
'git revert <hash>' creates a *new* commit that undoes the changes of a previous one.
Safe for public history because it doesn't rewrite the past, just adds to it.
'git clean -fd' removes untracked files and directories. Useful to cleanup build artifacts.
Be careful: these files cannot be recovered via Git.
'git blame <file>' shows who last modified each line of a file and when.
Don't use it to shame! Use it to find who to ask questions to.
'git diff' shows changes between your working directory and the staging area.
'git diff --staged' shows changes you are about to commit.
'git fetch' downloads info about remote changes but doesn't merge them.
It's safe to run anytime. Follow it with 'git merge' or 'git rebase' when you're ready.
'git log' lists the commit history. Press 'q' to exit.
Try 'git log --oneline --graph --all' for a visual tree of your history.
Tags are used to mark specific points in history as important, usually for releases (v1.0).
Use 'git tag -a v1.0 -m "Release 1.0"' to create an annotated tag.
'git remote -v' lists all connected remote repositories.
'git remote add origin <url>' connects your local repo to GitHub.
It means you checked out a specific commit instead of a branch. If you make commits here, they can be lost easily. Create a branch to save them!
Submodules allow you to keep a Git repository as a subdirectory of another Git repository.
Git LFS (Large File Storage) replaces large files like audio/video with text pointers inside Git, storing the file contents elsewhere.
Issues are used to track bugs, enhancements, or tasks. Always search before creating a new one!
You can link PRs to issues using keywords like 'Fixes #123' in your PR description.
Push your branch, go to the GitHub repo, and you'll usually see a 'Compare & pull request' button.
Fill out the template! Explain what you did and why.
GitHub Projects lets you organize issues and PRs in Kanban-style boards.
Great for roadmap planning and tracking sprint progress.
Discussions are for open-ended conversations, Q&A, and ideas that aren't quite 'issues' yet.
It's like a forum built right into the repository.
GitHub Actions automates workflows (like testing, building, deploying) directly in your repo.
Workflows are defined in .github/workflows/*.yml files.
GitHub Pages hosts static websites directly from your repository for free.
Perfect for project documentation or personal portfolios.
Wikis provide a place for long-form documentation alongside your code.
They are actually separate Git repositories that you can clone and edit locally!
Releases are packaged versions of your software, based on Git tags.
They often contain changelogs and compiled binaries for users to download.
GitHub Sponsors allows the community to financially support the people who build the open source software they use.
You can sponsor individuals or organizations.
Forking creates a copy of the repo on your GitHub account. It's the standard way to contribute to projects you don't own.
You push changes to your fork, then open a Pull Request to the original (upstream) repo.
npm is the standard package manager for Node.js. 'npm install' downloads dependencies listed in package.json.
package.json is the manifest file for your project. Don't touch node_modules manually!
pip is the package installer for Python. 'pip install -r requirements.txt' installs dependencies.
Always use a virtual environment (venv) to isolate project dependencies!
Maven (pom.xml) and Gradle (build.gradle) are the main build tools for Java.
They handle dependencies, compilation, and packaging (JAR/WAR).
Cargo is Rust's package manager and build system. 'cargo build' compiles, 'cargo test' runs tests.
Dependencies are defined in Cargo.toml. Crates.io is the package registry.
Go Modules (go.mod) manage dependencies in Go. 'go get' adds a dependency.
Go emphasizes simplicity. Dependencies are downloaded directly from their source repos.
Bus Factor serves as a metaphor for the number of team members that would need to be hit by a bus (or leave) for the project to stall.
A low bus factor is risky. Documentation and shared knowledge increase it.
Bikeshedding happens when a team spends too much time debating trivial details (like the color of a bike shed) while ignoring complex issues.
Recognize it and move on!
Yak shaving is a series of small, seemingly unrelated tasks you have to perform before you can do the thing you actually want to do.
'I wanted to fix a bug, but first I had to update the OS, which required...'
A heated argument on the internet, often getting personal. Avoid them! Focus on technical merits.
If a thread gets toxic, disengage. Maintainers may lock the conversation.
BDFL (Benevolent Dictator For Life) refers to a leader who has final say in disputes (e.g., Linus Torvalds for Linux).
It's a common governance model, contrasting with consensus-based models.
Permissive. Do whatever you want, just keep the copyright notice.
Permissive, but protects you from patent trolling. Used by Google, Android, Kubernetes.
Copyleft. Changes must be open sourced under the same license.
Like GPL, but closes the 'SaaS loophole'. If you run it on a server for users, you must share changes.
Very similar to MIT. The '3-clause' version prohibits using the author's name for endorsement.
Dedicating the work to the public domain. No restrictions at all.
Usually for content (images, text), not code. CC-BY requires attribution. CC-BY-SA is copyleft for content.
Linting analyzes code for potential errors and stylistic issues without running it.
Always lint before pushing! It saves time in code review.
Code coverage measures how much of your code is executed by tests. Aim for high coverage!
Unit tests check small parts; integration tests check how they work together.
CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) is a list of publicly disclosed security flaws.
Keep your dependencies updated to avoid known CVEs.
Never report security bugs in public issues! Check the SECURITY.md file for an email address.
This is called 'responsible disclosure'â€”giving maintainers time to fix it before hackers find it.
Google Summer of Code (GSoC) is a global program that offers stipends to contributors for working on open source projects.
It happens every summer (May-August). You need to write a proposal for a participating organization.
Social Summer of Code (SSOC) is a 10-week open-source program designed for beginners to get started with contribution.
It usually runs in the summer and offers swags and certificates.
Social Winter of Code (SWOC) is an open-source program that runs in winters (Jan-Mar), aimed at introducing students to open source.
It's a great alternative if you missed summer programs! Beginners are very welcome.
GirlScript Summer of Code (GSSoC) is a 3-month long open source program. Whether you are a beginner or an expert, GSSoC is open to everyone.
It's famous for being extremely beginner-friendly and having a vast number of projects.
Outreachy provides paid, remote internships for people subject to systemic bias and those from underrepresented groups in tech.
It runs twice a year (May-Aug and Dec-Mar). The application process involves an initial eligibility check and a contribution period.
The MLH Fellowship is a 12-week internship alternative where you contribute to major open source projects like React, Meta, etc.
It's very competitive and simulates a real-world software engineering environment.
LFX Mentorship (formerly CommunityBridge) offers paid mentorships for working on Linux Foundation projects (Kubernetes, CNCF, etc.).
It runs year-round in different terms (Spring, Summer, Fall).
Hacktoberfest requires 4 valid Pull Requests to opted-in repositories during October.
Always check for the 'hacktoberfest' topic on the repo. Spammy PRs will get you disqualified!
You must be at least 18 years old and eligible to work in your country of residence. You don't need to be a student anymore!
GSoC usually announces orgs in Feb. Contributor proposals are due in April. Coding happens May-August. Results in September.
Stipends vary by country (PPP based). It can range from $1500 to $3000+. It's paid in two installments (mid-term and final).
SSOC is open to everyone! There are no age restrictions or specific qualifications. Beginners are highly encouraged.
SSOC typically runs from June to August. Registration usually starts in May.
Participants can win T-shirts, stickers, badges, and certificates based on the points they earn on the leaderboard.
SWOC is open to all students and professionals. No prerequisites required, just a zeal to learn!
SWOC is a winter program. Registrations: Dec. Coding: Jan-Feb. Results: March.
Top contributors get cool swag kits (T-shirts, stickers), certificates, and sometimes internship opportunities with partner companies.
Despite the name 'GirlScript', GSSoC is open to ALL genders and nationalities. Everyone can participate!
GSSoC is a 3-month program, usually running from May to August. Registrations open around Feb-March.

patterns: what do i get from gssoc
responses: Certificate of Appreciation, Top performers get Swag kits, and internship opportunities with hiring partners.
You must be available for full-time internship work. Open to women (cis/trans), trans men, non-binary people, and all underrepresented groups in tech.
Yes! Outreachy interns are paid a stipend of $7,000 USD for the 3-month internship.
Rounds happen twice a year. May-Aug round (apply in Jan/Feb). Dec-Mar round (apply in Aug/Sep).
Open to students and recent graduates who know how to code. You must be able to commit 30 hours/week.
They have three tracks: 'Open Source' (contribute to big projects), 'Software Engineering' (work on partner projects), and 'Web3'.
It is a scholarship program. They provide a diverse educational stipend based on need and location, significantly covering living costs.
Eligibility varies by project, but generally open to anyone who is not currently a maintainer of the project they are applying to.
Yes, LFX mentorships are paid! Stipends are adjusted based on your location and can be around $3000-$6000 USD.
You're testing the limits of my knowledge! Try asking about git commands, specific languages, or community terms.
I might not know that one yet. Ask me about 'forking', 'npm', 'flamewars', or 'MIT license'!
